title: Development of a new 3D transverse laser profiling system for the automatic measurement of road cracks
segmentation: Thank you Paul.
I'm going to talk to you about the 3D system we've been developing over many years now.
We've been doing this project in close collaboration with the Kubecka Ministry of Transportation, and unfortunately, a magical day isn't here because he.
He did a lot of the work in terms of validating the results of.
Of the surveys we did in Québec using this system, and I do have several slides at the end that.
That are preliminary results, but for a lot of data and and so it's too bad he's not here.
So to present these results to you.
Now as I know I did this most of the work was done with my colleague Daniela 5 and Eric Samsung.
And then.
Basically, what what?
What were the premise of doing this system was instead of?

Trying to do crack surveys using images and image processing techniques, we decided to develop a very high performance 3D sensor so that we could see cracks, a see a level of cracks and cracked detail, macro texture and things like that so.
Why 3D instead of?
Processing images when you look at an image right away if its image is good quality, you will see visually you will very well see the cracks and then.
The human brain is pretty good processor, but it's very difficult to program a computer to to be able to extract the.
The cracks from images, whereas when you're looking at a 3D profile of a crack.
It's it's pretty evident that you will see all of a sudden a drop in in the 3D profile, so.
While it may be difficult to.
Get very good 3D data.
On cracks because it takes a lot of computer power, it takes a lot of specialized optics and electronics.
When you come to process the data.
It's maybe a more reliable source in this is the premise that we've been working on, and when I we also do imaging systems.
And one of the interesting things we learned when we do imaging systems for cracks is if you don't project shadows.
If you don't have a lighting system that will project the shadow, it's it's not possible to see the crack in the images.
So what?
This is telling us is that.
The crack is in fact a 3D entity because you have to have lighting coming at an angle to project the shadow so.
The fact that we can see cracks kind of indicates that they exist in three dimensions, not just too so.
Without further ado, present the first slide.
I guess I'll start by presenting the sensor themselves.
There is a some specialized.
Tricks we do to get more data out from the cameras and some of this is described in the paper.

But in terms of sensors themselves, currently the version that was tested by the MTQ.
Is a is these two sensors?
They both look down on the I'll show you on the vehicle later.
They both cover each two meters of Rd for a total of 4 meters.

It's a lot of data, so it's 2002.6 gigabytes of data per kilometer, but we have put into place image compression algorithms and data compression algorithms for the 3D profiles and it gets down to a very manageable 188 to 180 megabytes per kilometers of data.

It's not very complicated technique.

Very useful items that look you can scan roads with him too.

And?

Each point here goes up or down gives me my distance to my camera, and by measuring the difference between this number of pixels here in this summer pixels there I can get the height of the plank or.
The depth of the crack.
